abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Elementary Education Project for India, which aims to
            universalize elementary education by community ownership of
            the school system. This report identifies probable
            environmental issues and impacts and comprises various
            manuals, documents, and guidelines that have been
            disseminated to the states to address such issues. The
            salient theme is: community participation in planning and
            construction ensures that implementation is free from
            potential environmental hazards. Site selection will
            consider the location's vulnerability to natural
            hazards (flooding, cyclone, earthquakes); ensure buildings
            are designed according to code, for disaster prevention;
            prefabricated school structures will be dismantled and
            shifted to new location to avoid flooding; and some schools
            are designed to double up as shelters. Facility related
            impacts include locating water facility to avoid
            waterlogging, reusing wastewater to flush toilets or water
            plants; rain water harvesting; using toilets designed on the
            twin pit system; and alternatively, using septic tanks only
            where the water table is very low and there is a
            contamination risk. Encourage hedges and green fencing as
            environmentally-friendly options for school boundaries.
            Address basic site management  issues such as reducing
            wastage, ensuring safety, avoiding damage to flora and
            fauna, restricting air and noise pollution, and work
            scheduling. Choose school construction materials that avoid
            potentially hazardous materials like asbestos and minimally
            deplete natural resources. Use alternate technologies like
            rat trap bond wall, filler slab roof, and stub foundations,
            and promote less energy-intensive alternatives that are
            maintainable, replicable, and durable like stabilized mud
            block, fly ash brick, brick corbelled structures, etc.
